feed.title: Atom.X
feed.subtitle: Atom's webpages, an IT farmer, remote worker, Aaronic priest.

entry.title: Small town lifestyle
entry.content:
As the reason you all known, I came to Europe as a backpacker for sometimes.

March 2023- Europe

I traveled through numerous towns, meet people with diversity ethnics and backgrounds. After upheaval and displacementâ€¦ later I worked in an E-commerce company in big city, handling online orders and warehouse for thousands of offline stores and Amazon.

Current Mindset: I live peacefully, and I donâ€™t lack material things, but I feel a strong sense of crisis and anxiety usually, especially since great pandemic. Someday circumstances might force us to change lifestyle, we have to move far away from big cities and modern civilization.

Getting Prepared: To be ready for unexpected events, I believe we should learn basic self-sufficiency skills. These skills, rooted in essential knowledge, can help us navigate challenging times.

Lifestyle: I find contentment as an â€œIT farmer,â€ living in a picturesque and prosperous small town. My days strike a harmonious balance between physical and mental work â€” code with left hand and farm with right.

Daily Routines: Half of my time is dedicated to an online computer programming boot-camp. The other half involves part-time work alongside farm owners and landlords.

I engage in diverse tasks: herding horses and sheep, beekeeping, house repairs, gardening, growing fruits and vegetables, and caring for children.

Entrepreneurial Vision: Calling all like-minded partners! If you resonate with this lifestyle, I have wonderful commitments for the future. Letâ€™s explore various locations across continents on earth.

Together, weâ€™ll establish horticultural farms, share workspaces, engage in remote work, contribute to community service, and champion open-source initiatives.
entry.summary: As the reason you all known, I came to Europe as a backpacker for sometimes.

entry.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W4
entry.content:
Quantifier(logic)

$âˆ€$ , For All, Conjunction, âˆ§, all things $âˆƒ$, Exist, Disjunction, âˆ¨, at least one

$âˆƒx$[$A(x) âˆ§ B(x)$] â‰  $âˆƒx\(A(x)$ âˆ§ $âˆƒx\)B(x)$, False

There is a game player who is both an attacker and a defender.

There is a game player who is an attacker, and There is a game player(another one?) who is a defender.

$âˆƒx$[$A(x) âˆ¨ B(x)$] = $âˆƒx\(A(x)$ **âˆ¨** $âˆƒx\)B(x)$

There is a game player who is an attacker or a defender.

There is a game player who is an attacker, or who is a defender.

$âˆ€x$[$A(x) âˆ¨ B(x)$] â‰  $âˆ€x\(A(x)$ âˆ¨ $âˆ€x\)B(x)$, False

All nature number are even or odd

All nature number are even, or All nature number are odd

$âˆ€x$[$A(x) âˆ§ B(x)$] = $âˆ€x\(A(x)$ âˆ§ $âˆ€x\)B(x)$

All athletes are both strong and big

All athletes are strong, and all athletes are big.

entry.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W3 Assignment 5
entry.content:
(âˆ€ğ‘šâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(âˆƒğ‘›â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(ğ‘›>ğ‘š), True

  • Express the existence assertions

a. ($âˆƒx$â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($x^3 = 27$ )

b. ($âˆƒğ‘›$â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(ğ‘›>10000)

c. natural number n is not a prime ($âˆƒp$â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($âˆƒm$â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($p$>1 âˆ§ $m$>1 âˆ§ $n=pm$)

  • Express the â€˜for allâ€™ assertions

a. ($âˆ€x$ âˆ‰â€ˆâ„•)($x^3$ = 28) Â¬($âˆƒx$ âˆˆâ€ˆ$â„•$)($x^3$ = 28) ($âˆ€x$ âˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($x^3$ â‰  28)

($âˆ€x$ âˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)Â¬($x^3$ = 28)

b. ($âˆ€n$ âˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($n>0$ ) c. ($âˆ€p$ âˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)($âˆ€q$ âˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)[( **$n=pq$) **â‡’$n=pqn=pq$$p$=1 V $q=1$ )]

  • quantifiers for people

a. ($âˆ€x$)($âˆƒy$) $L(x,y)$, where $L(x,y)$ denotes â€œ$x$ love $y$â€

b. ($âˆ€x$) [Tall$(x)$ V Short$(x)$]

c. [($âˆ€x$) Tall$(x)$] V [($âˆ€x)$ Short$(x)$]

d. ($âˆ€n$)[Â¬ At-home$(n)$] ($Â¬âˆƒn$)[At-home$(n)$]

e. if John comes, all the women will leave. Come$(John)$ â‡’ $âˆ€x$[Woman$(x)$ â‡’Leave$(x)$]

f. if a man comes, all the women will leave. ($âˆƒx$)[Man$(x)$ âˆ§ Comes$(x)$] â‡’ ($âˆ€x$)[Woman$(x)$â‡’Leave$(x)$]

  • Express quantifiers

a. the equation $x^2$ + a = 0 has a real root for any real number a. ($x^2$ + a = 0) âˆ§ [($âˆƒx$, $âˆ€a$) âˆˆ $R$]?

($âˆ€a$ âˆˆ $R$)($âˆƒx$âˆˆ $R$)($x^2$ + a = 0) Donâ€™t mistake the order, â€œreal number aâ€ should be on first, then follows others, because â€œxâ€ depends on â€œaâ€. otherwise, it will be wrong express, take â€œAmerican Melanoma Foundationâ€ for example.

b. the equation $x^2$ + a = 0 has a real root for any negative real number a. ($âˆ€a$âˆˆR)[(a<0)â‡’($âˆƒx$âˆˆR)($x^2$ + a = 0)]

c. Every real number is rational. (False statement)

($âˆ€a$ âˆˆ $R$)($âˆƒx$âˆˆ $N$)($âˆƒy$âˆˆ $N$)(a=x/y V a=-x/y V a=0)

($âˆ€a$ âˆˆ $R$)($âˆƒx$âˆˆ $Z$)($âˆƒy$âˆˆ $Z$)(a=x/y, V a=0)? is it a right solution?

R, Real number,

Q, Rational number, x/y of two integers.

Z, [Integer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_(computer_science)) number(+, -)

N, Nature number, non-negative integersÂ 0, 1, 2, 3, â€¦â€¦ N

R>Q>Z>N, the order is from big to small number set.

d. there is an irrational number. ($âˆƒa$ âˆˆ $R$)($âˆ€x$âˆˆ $N$)($âˆ€y$âˆˆ $N$)(aâ‰ x/y âˆ§ aâ‰ -x/y)

e. there is no largest rational number {($âˆ€i$, $âˆƒir$) âˆˆ $R$$Q$}($i>ir$)?

($âˆ€r$âˆˆ$R$)($âˆƒp$âˆˆ$R$)[(p>r)âˆ§($âˆ€m$âˆˆ$N$)($âˆ€n$âˆˆ$N$) (pâ‰ m/n)]

For all real number r, there is an number p, when p is greater than r, and for all nature number m and n, p is not equal to that m divided by n, so p is irrational number, it means that there is always an irrational number greater than a real number r.

  • Express in symbolic form

a. ($âˆ€x$âˆˆC)[D$(x)$ â‡’ M$(x)$]

b. ($âˆ€x$âˆˆC)[Â¬D(x) â‡’ M(x)]

c. ($âˆ€x$âˆˆC)[M(x) â‡’ D(x)], universal quantifier $âˆ€x$, usually compare it with conditional implication â‡’

d. ($âˆƒx$âˆˆC)[D(x)âˆ§ Â¬M(x)], existential quantifier $âˆƒx$âˆˆ, typically compare it with conjunction âˆ§

e. ($âˆƒx$âˆˆC)[Â¬D(x) âˆ§ M(x)]

  • You can find a rational number between any two unequal real number.

$âˆ€x$ $âˆ€y${(x<y) â‡’$âˆƒz$ $âˆƒz$ $Q(z)$ âˆ§(x<z<y)]}

  • Abraham Lincoln : â€œYou may fool all the people some of the time, you can even fool some of the people all of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all the time.â€

F$(p,t)$ = You may fool people p, at time t.

[F($âˆ€p$ âˆ§ $âˆƒt$) V ($âˆ€t$ âˆ§ $âˆƒp$)] âˆ§[Â¬ Fool ($âˆ€t$ âˆ§ $âˆ€p$ )]

($âˆƒt\(âˆ€p$ âˆ§ $âˆƒp\)âˆ€t$ âˆ§ Â¬$âˆ€t$$âˆ€p$)F$(p,t)$ ? is it a right solution?

$âˆƒt\(âˆ€p$F$(p,t)$ âˆ§ $âˆƒp\)âˆ€t$F$(p,t)$ âˆ§ Â¬$âˆ€t$$âˆ€p$)F$(p,t)$

Something = $âˆƒ$

  • A driver is involved in an accident every six seconds. False statement, ambiguous

A(d, t) , Driver in d, an accident in a, every six seconds in t

$âˆƒd$ $âˆ€t$(t= every 6 seconds)A$(d,t)$

8.1 Every six seconds A driver is involved in an accident. True statement, precise.

$âˆ€t$ $âˆƒd$ A$(d,t)$

Quiz

  • 1 d. they win exactly a match when they are partners. $(âˆƒ!t)$ W(t) f. If Rosario wins the match, she must be partnering with Antonio. the Scope is double tennis, it is not in this case that only Rosario.

  • there is no largest prime.

$âˆ€x$$âˆƒy$ [Prime(x)âˆ§Prime(y)âˆ§(x<y)], $âˆ€x$ $âˆ€y$ [Prime(x)âˆ§Prime(y)âˆ§(x<y)],

$âˆƒy$ $âˆ€x$[Prime(x)âˆ§(y<x)], $âˆ€x$ Prime(x) is False. Because there exist lots of Prime number x that is not greater than natural number y. so we can not set $âˆ€x$ Prime(x)

  • Evaluate this purported proof, according to the course rubric.

PS3_Q6.pdf 4+3+2+0+0+2 = 11 ?

Teacherâ€™s standard answer 4+0+0+4+0+2=10

entry.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W3
entry.content:
the most difficult lecture

Analysis of language - quantifiers

irrational numbers

âˆ€ for all

âˆƒ there exists

express an existence assertion. a confident and forceful statement of fact or belief.

Combination of quantifiers

there is no largest natural number.

(âˆ€ğ‘šâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(âˆƒğ‘›â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(ğ‘›>ğ‘š), True

(âˆƒğ‘›â€ˆâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(âˆ€ğ‘šâˆˆâ€ˆâ„•)(ğ‘›>ğ‘š), False

American Melanoma Foundation: â€œOne American dies of Melanoma almost every hour.â€

âˆƒAâˆ€H(A dies in hour H), False, misunderstanding: An American dies once every hour, ridiculous.

âˆ€HâˆƒA(A dies in hour H), True

parentheses()

b. Ï† â‡” Ïˆ is false if exactly one of Ï†, Ïˆ is true and the other false.

b. explain modus ponens

[Ï† âˆ§ (Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ)] â‡’ Ïˆ are all TRUE.

modus ponens: if you know Ï† and you know Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ, then you can conclude Ïˆ.

5. Prove Equivalence

by means of a logical argument, in natural language, we can deduce that

Â¬(Ï†âˆ§Ïˆ) â‡” (Â¬Ï†)âˆ¨(Â¬Ïˆ)

  1. (Ï†âˆ§Ïˆ) , both Ï† and Ïˆ are true
  2. Â¬(Ï†âˆ§Ïˆ) , not the case that both Ï† and Ïˆ are true
  3. If they are not both true, then at least one of Ï† or Ïˆ must be false
  4. the same as saying that, at least one of Â¬Ï† or Â¬Ïˆ is true

  5. (Â¬Ï†)âˆ¨(Â¬Ïˆ)

  6. This is clearly the same as saying that at least one of Â¬Ï† and Â¬Ïˆ is true. (By the definition of negation). here is an error, please change â€œandâ€ to â€œorâ€

Â¬(Ï†âˆ¨Ïˆ) â‡” (Â¬Ï†)âˆ§(Â¬Ïˆ)

  1. (Ï†âˆ¨Ïˆ) , if either Ï† or Ïˆ is true, then it is true.
  2. Â¬(Ï†âˆ¨Ïˆ) , not the case that either Ï† or Ïˆ is true.
  3. if they are both false, then neither Ï† nor Ïˆ is true,
  4. the same as saying that, both Â¬Ï† and Â¬Ïˆ are true
  5. (Â¬Ï†)âˆ§(Â¬Ïˆ)

6. Denial statement

(a) 34,159 is (a composite number) not a prime number.

(b) Roses are not red or violets are not blue.

(c) If there are no hamburgers, I will have a hot dog.

Â¬(Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) = Ï† âˆ§ Â¬ Ïˆ, â€œâˆ§ conjunction uses but / andâ€

If there are no hamburgers, but I wonâ€™t have a hot dog.

(d) Fred will go but he will not play.

this sentence is interpreted as (Ï† âˆ§ Â¬ Ïˆ)

the denial statement as Â¬(Ï† âˆ§ Â¬ Ïˆ) 1. Â¬(Ï† âˆ§ Â¬ Ïˆ) â‡” (Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ),

1.1 if Fred will go, then he will play.

1.2 Fred will go, only if he will play.

1.3 Fred will play if he will go.

1.4 Fred will play whenever he will go.

  1. Â¬(Ï† âˆ§ Â¬ Ïˆ) â‡” Â¬ Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ

2.1 Fred will not go or he will play.

Â¬(Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ ) â‡” Â¬ Ï† âˆ§ Â¬Ïˆ

Â¬(Ï† âˆ§ Ïˆ ) â‡” Â¬ Ï† âˆ¨ Â¬Ïˆ

(e) The number x is either negative or greater than 10.

(x<0)âˆ¨(x>10) either or ä¸¤è€…ä»»ä¸€ disjunction âˆ¨.

Â¬ [(x<0)âˆ¨(x>10)] = (xâ‰¥0)âˆ§(xâ‰¤10) = 0â‰¤ x â‰¤10 The number x is non-negative and less than or equal to 10.

(f) We will win the first game or the second.

We will lose the first two games.

9. [Ï† â‡’ (Ïˆ âˆ§ Î¸)] â‡” [(Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) âˆ§ (Ï† â‡’ Î¸)]

10. Verify the equivalence of previous

by means of a logical argument, in natural language, we can deduce that

[Ï† â‡’ (Ïˆ âˆ§ Î¸)] and [(Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) âˆ§ (Ï† â‡’ Î¸)]

  1. Ï† â‡’ (Ïˆ âˆ§ Î¸)
  2. Ïˆ and Î¸ from Ï†
  3. Ïˆ from Ï†, and Î¸ from Ï†

  4. (Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) and (Ï† â‡’ Î¸)

  5. (Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) âˆ§ (Ï† â‡’ Î¸)

  6. [Ï† â‡’ (Ïˆ âˆ§ Î¸)] â‡” [(Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ) âˆ§ (Ï† â‡’ Î¸)]

c. (Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ )â‡’ Î¸ and (Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸)

  1. Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸
  2. **Î¸ from Ï† or Ïˆ
  3. **Î¸ from Ï† or **Î¸ from Ïˆ
  4. Ï† â‡’ Î¸ or Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸
  5. (Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸)
  6. [(Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ )â‡’ Î¸] â‡” [(Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸)]

c0. (Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸) and (Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ )â‡’ Î¸

  1. (Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸)
  2. Î¸ from Ï† or **Î¸ from Ïˆ
  3. Î¸ from Ï† or Ïˆ
  4. (Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ )â‡’ Î¸
  5. [ (Ï† â‡’ Î¸) âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Î¸)] â‡” [(Ï† âˆ¨ Ïˆ )â‡’ Î¸]

11. [Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ] â‡” [(Â¬Ïˆ) â‡’ (Â¬Ï†)]

Ï† Ïˆ Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ Â¬Ïˆ Â¬Ï† (Â¬Ïˆ) â‡’ (Â¬Ï†)

(Â¬Ïˆ) â‡’ (Â¬Ï†) is Contrapositives of Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ.

12. Contrapositives of the statements

(a) rectangles congruent â‡’ same area Contrapositives:

Â¬ same area â‡’ Â¬ rectangles congruent If two rectangles donâ€™t have the same area, they are not congruent.

(b) If a triangle with sides a, b, c (c largest) is right-angled, then $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$

Contrapositives:

  1. right-angled â‡’ $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$
  2. Â¬ ( $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$ ) â‡’ Â¬ right-angled

If a triangle with sides a, b, c (c largest) and $a^2 + b^2$ â‰  $c^2$, then it is not right-angled.

(c) ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) prime â‡’ $n$ prime

Contrapositives:

Â¬ $n$ prime â‡’ Â¬ ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) prime

If $n$ is not prime, then $2^n$ âˆ’ 1 is not prime.

(d) Yuan rise â‡’ Dollar fall

Contrapositives:

Â¬ Dollar fall â‡’ Â¬ Yuan rise

If the Dollar not fall, the Yuan will not rises.

13. Converse [Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ] â‡ [Ïˆ â‡’ Ï†]

Ï† Ïˆ Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ Ïˆ â‡’ Ï†
T T T T
T F F T
F T T F
F F T T

Donâ€™t confuse the contrapositive and converse

14. Converses of the statements 12

(a) rectangles congruent â‡’ same area Converses: rectangles same area â‡’ congruent If two rectangles have the same area, they are congruent. F

(b) triangle â‡’ $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$ Converses: ( $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$ ) â‡’ triangle If a triangle with sides a, b, c (c largest) and $a^2 + b^2$ = $c^2$, then it is a right-angled. T

(c) ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) prime â‡’ $n$ prime

Converses: $n$ prime â‡’ ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) prime

If $n$ is prime, then $2^n$ âˆ’ 1 is prime.

(d) Yuan rise â‡’ Dollar fall

Converses: Dollar fall â‡’ Yuan rise

If the Dollar fall, the Yuan will rises.

OPTIONAL PROBLEMS

8 Card puzzle

B, E, 4, 7

at least 3 cards as follows:

A, I, O, U

1, 3, 5, 9,

9. Prove that mn is odd iff m and n are odd.

â‡” iff = if only if = equivalence totally, double direction

mn is odd â‡” m and n are odd

mn= 15, m=3, n=5

mn= 39, m=3, n=13

True

10. Prove that mn is even iff m and n are even

mn is even â‡” m and n are even

mn=6, m=2, n=3

False

entry.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W2 QUIZ
entry.content:
Math Foundation of computing, Stanford university. Preliminary Course Notes - Keith Schwarz

implication has a truth part(conditional ) and a causation part.

implication = conditional + causation

conditional means â‡’

Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ is the truth part of â€œ Ï† implies Ïˆ â€.

Ï† is the antecedent

Ïˆ is the consequent define the truth of Ï†â‡’Ïˆ in terms of the truth/falsity of Ï† and Ïˆ.

Equivalence Quiz

Which of the following conditions is necessary and sufficient for the natural number $n$ to be multiple of 10 ?

  1. $n$ is multiple of 5
  2. $n$ is multiple of 20
  3. $n$ is even and multiple of 5
  4. $n$ = 100
  5. $n^2$ is multiple of 100

Ï† = the natural number $n$ to be multiple of 10

Ïˆ = following conditions

Ïˆ is necessary for Ï† means Ï†â‡’Ïˆ

Ïˆ is sufficient for Ï† means Ïˆâ‡’Ï†

answer: both the third and fifth are necessary and sufficient Ï† â‡” Ïˆ

explanation:

  1. if Ï†, then Ïˆ ;
  2. Ï† is sufficient for Ïˆ ;
  3. Ï† only if Ïˆ [not the same as â€œif Ïˆ, then Ï†â€ ] ;
  4. Ïˆ if Ï†;
  5. Ïˆ whenever Ï†;
  6. Ïˆ is necessary for **Ï†;

â‡” iff = if only if = equivalence totally, double direction

(Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ )âˆ§ (Ïˆ â‡’ Ï†) = Ï† â‡” Ïˆ

Ïˆ is necessary for Ï† means Ï†â‡’Ïˆ

Ï† is sufficient for Ïˆ means Ï†â‡’Ïˆ

donâ€™t confused the order of implication direction from one to another.

Antecedent â‡’ Consequent, Ï† â‡’ Ïˆ

if â€¦ **then, **only if,

if, whenever,

Keith cycles only if the sun shine, Antecedent is Keith cycles.

Keith â‡’ Sunshine, if Keith cycles, it is sufficient to prove that there must be Sunshine, good day.

it could not be reverse, because sunshine is a necessary reason, but not the sufficient reason that prove Keith cycles.

if there was a sunshine day, but Keith might not cycles, she has other options of activities, so Keith is the antecedent for the sunshine,

sufficient : must be the reason, Antecedent and Consequent could not be reverse, strong reason;

necessary: might be the reason, Antecedent and Consequent could be reverse, weak reason.

Vocabulary

notion: concept.

notation: symbol, sign

Material implication

Genuine Implication?

Material conditional

antecedents and consequences å‰å› å’Œåæœ

conditional

intuition ç›´è§‰

causality

genuine causation

nature number

QUIZ & Problem set.

Which one is antecedent?

  1. it is necessary that $n$ is prime in order for ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) to be prime.
    • A. $n$ is prime
    • B. ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) i prime.

interpret: $n$ is prime which is necessary (in order) for that ( $2^n$ âˆ’ 1) is (to be) prime. B â‡’ A

B is antecedent.

  1. The team wins only when Karl is playing.

A. team wins

B. Karl play.

interpret: The team wins only (if) when Karl is playing. A â‡’ B

A is antecedent.

  1. When Karl plays the team wins.

A. Karl plays

B. team wins

interpret: When followed by Antecedent. A â‡’ B

A is antecedent.

  1. The team wins when Karl plays.

A. Karl plays

B. team wins

interpret: When followed by Antecedent. A â‡’ B

A is antecedent.

  1. For natural number m, n, is it truth that mn is even iff m and n are even?

**interpret:

if mn is even, then m and n are even

if m and n are even, then mn is even.

m=2, n=3, mn=6

False

iff means two implication equivalence, double direction are equal. mn means m multiply n, mxn

  1. is it truth that mn is odd iff m and n are odd?

interpret:

if mn is odd, then m and n are odd

if m and n are odd, then mn is odd.

m=1, n=3, mn=3

True

entry.title: Mathematical Thinking Stanford, W1 Assignment 2
entry.content:
1. Simplify the symbolic statements.

(b) (pâ‰¥7)âˆ§(p<12), 7â‰¤p<12

(c) (x>5)âˆ§(x<7), 5<x<7

(d) (x<4)âˆ§(x<6), x<4

(e) $(y<4)âˆ§(y^2 <9), y^2<9$

(f) (xâ‰¥0)âˆ§(xâ‰¤0), x=0

2. Express each of your simplified statements from question 1 in natural English.

(b) p is greater than or equal to 7 and less than 12.

(c) x is greater than 5, and less than 7.

(d) x is less than 4

(e) y squared is less than 9

(f) x is equal to 0

3. What strategy would you adopt to show that the conjunction Ï†1 âˆ§ Ï†2 âˆ§ . . . âˆ§ Ï†n is true?

show that all of Ï†1 , Ï†2 , . . . , Ï†n are true

4. What strategy would you adopt to show that the conjunction Ï†1 âˆ§ Ï†2 âˆ§ . . . âˆ§ Ï†n is false?

show that one of Ï†1 , Ï†2 , . . . , Ï†n is false.

5. Simplify the symbolic statements

(a) (Ï€>3)âˆ¨(Ï€>10), Ï€>3 (b) (x<0)âˆ¨(x>0), xâ‰ 0 (c) (x=0)âˆ¨(x>0), xâ‰¥0 (d) (x>0)âˆ¨(xâ‰¥0), xâ‰¥0 (e) (x>3)âˆ¨($x^2$ >9), $x^2$ >9

6. Express the above symbolic statements in natural English.

(a) Ï€ is greater than 3

(b) x is not equal to 0

(c) x is equal to or greater than 0

(d) x is equal to or greater than 0

(e) x squared is greater than 9

7. What strategy would you adopt to show that the disjunction Ï†1 âˆ¨ Ï†2 âˆ¨ . . . âˆ¨ Ï†n is true?

show that one of Ï†1 , Ï†2 , . . . , Ï†n is true

8. What strategy would you adopt to show that the disjunction Ï†1 âˆ¨ Ï†2 âˆ¨ . . . âˆ¨ Ï†n is false?

show that all Ï†1 , Ï†2 , . . . , Ï†n are false

9. Simplify the symbolic statements

(a) Â¬(Ï€ > 3.2), Ï€ â‰¤ 3.2 (b) Â¬(x < 0), x â‰¥ 0 (c) Â¬($x^2$ > 0), x = 0 (d) Â¬(x = 1), xâ‰ 1 (e) Â¬Â¬Ïˆ, Ïˆ

10. Express the above symbolic statements in natural English.

(a) negation of / not the case that Pai is greater than 3.2, Pai is less than and equal to 3.2 (b) negation of / not the case that x is less than 0, x is greater than and equal to 0 (c) negation of / not the case that x squared is greater than 0, x is equal to 0 (d) negation of / not the case that x equal to 1, x not equal to 1 (e) double negation of / not the case that Ïˆ(Psi), Ïˆ

11. Express in logical notation

(a) D âˆ§ Y

(b) Â¬Y âˆ§ T âˆ§ D

(c) Â¬(Y âˆ§ D)

(d) T âˆ§ Â¬Y âˆ§ Â¬D

(e) Â¬T âˆ§ Y âˆ§ D

DISCUSS

Guilty and Proven

Truth Table, Binary logic, True or False

G P G âˆ§ P Â  description

T F F âœ˜ Incorrectly Proven Innocent

Not disPleased is neutral, this is not a binary logic but a triary logic

triary logic

Positive neutral Negative

Â¬ displeased â‰  pleased

When calculate triary logic , mark a number(1 or 2) in each block , and must always track the same number for each calculation.

eg. (Ï† âˆ§ Ïˆ) âˆ§ Î¸ = (Ï† âˆ§ Ïˆ)F(1) âˆ§ Î¸T(1) = F(1)

(Ï† âˆ§ Ïˆ) âˆ¨ Î¸ = (Ï† âˆ§ Î¸) âˆ¨ (Ïˆ âˆ§ Î¸)

Vocabulary

Prime numbers

Caculus å¾®ç§¯åˆ†

Elements of Set Theory

integers æ•´æ•°

rational numbers (fractions) æœ‰ç†æ•°ï¼ˆåˆ†æ•°ï¼‰?

real numbers å®æ•°

arbitrary real number ä»»æ„å®æ•°?

the property

ambiguously precisely

the most important reason for using language precisely is more advanced parts of mathematics? **Advanced mathematics is very **abstract, and language is the only means we have to access it and decide what is true and what is false.

1. Ambiguous sentences

1.1 Each subscriberÂ toÂ a newspaperÂ inÂ Washington, DC.

1.1.1 Each subscriberÂ toÂ a newspaperÂ published inÂ Washington, DC.

1.1.2 Each newspaper subscriber who lives in Washington, DC.

1.2 John saw Jane driving down the street.

1.2.1 John, while driving down the street, saw Jane.

1.2.2 John saw Jane, who was driving down the street.

1.3 The man saw the woman with a telescope.

1.3.1 The man saw the woman who with a telescope.

1.3.2 The man with a telescope saw the woman.

2. Ambiguous Newspaper headlines

(a) Sisters reunited after ten years in checkout line at Safeway.

a.1 Sisters used to meet in checkout line at Safeway, then ten years passed by, they Reunited in somewhere else.

a.2 Sisters used to meet in somewhere else, then ten years passed by, they Reunited in checkout line at Safeway.

(b) Large hole appears in High Street. City authorities are looking into it.

b.1 ~, City authorities are looking into the hole.

b.2 ~, City authorities are looking into the High street.

(c) Mayor says bus passengers should be belted.

c.1 ~, there are no belts on the bus right now.

c.2 ~, there are belts on the bus right now.

3. No head injury is too trivial to ignore.

3.1 Except Head injury, the other kinds of patients could not be ignored.

3.2 Head injury is too trivial to ignore, NO! nothing special or serious, it could be ignored.

4. In case of fire, do not use elevator

4.1 Do not use elevator, during a fire.

4.2 Do not use elevator, it might cause the fire.

5. This page intentionally left blank

5.1 The pages after this one are intentionally left blank.

Tips: Even This page is not blank, because this one sentence.

6. Writer not intended

without the context, the writer will be misunderstood.

Windows is the best Operating System Bill gates: Windows is the best Operating System, affordable for Super Maria Game players before 2000.

Examples produced by GPT.

6.1 Example from â€œThe Guardian,â€ November 29, 2019:

  • Sentence: â€œThe man hit the nail on the head, and it was a real headache.â€
  • Intended Meaning: The man accurately identified a problem or solution, which caused relief.
  • Literal Misinterpretation: The man physically struck a nail with his head, resulting in a headache.

6.2 Example from â€œThe New York Times,â€ March 14, 2018:

  • Sentence: â€œThe chef who murdered his wife finally received his just desserts.â€
  • Intended Meaning: The chef who committed a crime against his wife faced the appropriate consequences.
  • Literal Misinterpretation: The chef who killed his spouse was served a dessert as a form of punishment.

6.3 Example from â€œCNN,â€ May 5, 2020:

  • Sentence: â€œScientists discovered a new strain of bacteria in the hospital, raising concerns among patients.â€
  • Intended Meaning: The discovery of the new bacteria strain in the hospital worried patients.
  • Literal Misinterpretation: Scientists found a new type of bacteria growing in the hospital, physically raising it, causing concern among patients.

7. Comment on the sentence â€œThe temperature is hot today.â€

using appropriate scientific terminologies, properties and values to express the weather or climate precisely

The temperature is about 35 degrees Celsius in the middle noon, weather is hot today.

8. N = (p1 Â·p2 Â·p3 Â· â€¦ Â·$p_n$)+1, $p_n$ is is prime, prove not every N is prime.

N = 2Â·3Â·5Â·7Â·8Â·9 + 1 = 15121

by Prime Number Calculator

JUST FOR FUN

1. â€œandâ€ occurs five times in succession.

A billionaire who inherited rich oil inheritance has 72 wives and countless children and grandchildren that he cannot name them. Whenever a large family gathering is held, he always sits on the super luxurious Bentley wheelchair inlaid with gold, he pointed at two children each time with his only two movable fingers, muttering incoherently: and, and, and, andâ€¦ to let the children came to receive gifts on a big table filled with precious stones . As for why he had 72 wives? The number of children he has is uncontrollable. According to his belief, only man who go to heaven deserve this auspicious number.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆä»–è¦å¨¶72ä½å¦»å­ï¼Ÿä»¥è‡³äºæ— æ³•æ§åˆ¶å­©å­çš„æ•°é‡ã€‚æ ¹æ®ä»–çš„ä¿¡ä»°ï¼Œåªæœ‰è¿›å…¥å¤©å ‚çš„ç”·äººï¼Œæ‰é…å¾—ä¸Š72è¿™ä¸ªå‰ç¥¥æ•°å­—ã€‚

2. and, or, and, or, and occur in that order, with no other word between them.

Among Python logical operators, you often use and, or, and, or, and.

Daniel Damerau: Several companies with ambiguous abbreviations, like AND, OR and OR, and some others are obviously unknown to the general population.

For instance, AND means â€œAmerican Natural Dwellingsâ€ (ha-ha), while OR and OR means â€œOregon Rangers and Olympic Routesâ€?
